Pours a glowy golden orange. Quite cloudy. I avoided pouring some chunks into my glass, but there are lots of floaties at the bottom of the bottle. Very large puffy white head. Hard to keep it under control during the pour. The aroma has a big dose of soft funk on top of fresh grain. Very pleasant. It smells like a tropical fruit barnyard. Flowers, leather, mangoes, mushrooms and earth. Wonderful brett notes. Very mild medicinal character. Seemed a bit strong, at first, but it settled into the rest of the beer after a minute. The taste starts with fruity grain sweetness before drying out with funk and adding a touch of lemony tartness. Lots of funky, fruity brett flavor. Mushrooms, lemons, barnyard. I try not to avoid esoteric notes, but it sorta tastes like unripe kiwi. Finishes quite dry with medium to mild bitterness. Grassy hops. Effervescent mouthfeel at first. Definitely reminds me of other brett beers. Personally, I prefer it with a bit less gas, and the carbonation fades quite quickly. Pretty smooth feel after a minute, actually. Otherwise, its light but full on the palate. Very well suited to the beer and style. No booze. Exceptionally easy to drink. Wonderful balance. This is the sort of beer that I would drink be happy to drink regularly. Surprisingly good price, too, particularly compared to most recent TLA bottles. Anyway, Im quite impressed by this one. Great beer.

Pour out of 375 mL bottle, hazy orange pour with tons of pillowy white head, aroma brought notes of pine, grass, some slight biscuit, bread, lemon peel, slight brett notes but more the fruity and slightly grassy type, hints of slight spice.  Taste is a mix of sweet bread, biscuit, lots of yeast, spice, going into some slightly funky brett, hints of white fruits but go away fast with grass and pine, finishing dry, bitter.  Pretty nice, wish there was a touch of tartness to balance the massive bitter and dry notes but a tasty version of the regular.

UPDATED: APR 11, 2013 Pours a slightly hazy orange golden color with a huge billowing wispy white foam... three plus fingers, takes time to let it settle to finish the pour.  The nose is vinous horse blanket, pineapple, citrus rind and a light dose of peppered spice. The palate follows the nose nicely with a heavy brux profile. Big rustic leather notes are lightened by fresh juicy pineapple, peach and traces of bubble gum. Nice grassy funk bitters out the mid to late palate and dries out on the back end nicely.

Bottle.  Pours an opaque golden with a big white head.  Aroma is super fruity; citrus, preserves, Belgian yeast, a little acidity and just a hint of brett.  Taste is mild-medium sweet, mild-medium bitter, and a tad sour.  Light-medium body, huge carbonation, refreshing.  This drinks a lot like a saison, and it certainly isnt a sour.

Bottle shared by bhensonb. Pours cloudy copper with a huge beige head that soon recedes to an artistic crag. There is a light fruity aroma and a slightly sour fruity malt flavor with a dry bitter finish. Easy to drink.

375 c&c from Bine and Vine. Pours very hazy orange amber with a five finger off-white head. Aroma is very smooth and mellow, yet sharpish, brett. Med body. Flavor is Belgian yeast/ester with earthy brett. Extremely tasty.

Pours hazy golden-orange with floating sediment and a giant, fluffy, light-beige head.  Aroma is intense, with yeast, barnyard, lemon, black pepper, and mild grape.  Flavor is relatively mellow with light malt, grassy hops, light bitterness, and a dry finish that on initial sips carries notes of ground pills/aspirin.  Excellent, and especially suited to a sunny spring day.

Pours pale gold into a tulip. Bright white head with medium retention recedes to coat surface. Tropical fruit and aspirin aromas. Crisp with sweet caramel and marshmallow upfront turning to aspirin, band-aid and a lasting earthy bitter pith finish.

Pours a very murky golden yellow color with a huge fluffy white head. Nose is a little estery and yeasty, theres some white grape, some brett funk, little bit of lemon and pepper too. A lot hoppier taste that I was expecting, mostly a citrus and grassy bitterness. Some spiciness to it, a light fruitiness too (peach, mango). Medium bodied and active carbonation. A great beer for a warm summer day.

375 ml corked and crowned bottle. Pours a hazy honey gold color with a big rocky white head with nice lacing. Obvious sourdough yeasty malt aroma is ripe with notes of lemon peel, white pepper and coriander. Bitter citrusy malt flavor. Lightly funky Brett character complements the biscuity maltiness and peppery hops. Very refreshing and complex.

Bottle at home. Pour is hazy orange with a big white head and great lacing. Super bretty, medicinal, band-aid, herbal, pineapple, mango, biscuit, straw, and pear in the aroma. Taste is big band-aid, herbs, pineapple, tropical fruits, light spice, citrus, lemon rind, biscuit, hay, and nice funk with a light bitter finish. Medium body with high carbonation. Seriously awesome use of brett and this one should age beautifully. Please make this year-round.

375ml c&c bottle from Cross Roads. Poured a muddy apple cider body with a HUGE pillowy white head that lasts and lasts. Aroma is a text book example of Brett, old band aids, lots of funk, souring lemon and cherry, antiseptic. Body is delicate with super light carbonation that finishes dry and watery. Flavor of Brett, band aid, dry grainy cracker, Bactene antiseptic spray. Aging this might bring out the Brett in the flavor a bit more but I dont think it can smell any more Brett than it already does.

Not that sour. Aroma is huge with lots of lemon, citrus and a little bit of funk. It almost smells sour. Pours a cloudy golden. Taste is spicy with notes of lemon, citrus and bitterness. Plenty of carbonation round off the mouth feel. A really tasty brew but not the sourness I expected. Maybe cellar it? Overall, a spicy brew with tons of great aroma.

2012 375 ml bottle.  Aroma of big musty.  Dusty peach skins. Pear.  Tangerines.   Sweaty Brett.  Everything comes together quite nicely.  Taste is lemongrass.  Fog.  Sweaty Brett.  Peaches.   Pretty solid all around.  One of the better beers Ive had from lost abbey and available right here on the shelf.  Fine.

Bottle. Pours light hazy orange with a huge off white head. Dissipates to lacing. Aroma is dominated by Brett. Some faint sweet fruit notes peek through. Taste opens with tropical fruit and banana and finishes with light earthy funk. Soft full mouthfeel and a dry finish. Not normally a Brett fan but this incorporates it really well. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

375 mL bottle from the Best Damn Beer Store in San Diego, served in a snifter. Pours hazy orange-amber with a moderate tan head that remains and leaves a small amount of fine lace. On the nose there are big notes of sour apple, grape, caramel and grain, along with earth, banana and spice. The flavour is moderately sweet and slightly tart with notes from the nose. It acquires a significant pepperiness towards the end. The finish is long, malty, fruity and funky. On the palate, it is medium in body with a dry texture and intense carbonation. Overall, this is a nice Bretty sour Belgian style blonde ale with a peppery finish. The Brett adds an interesting twist, but it makes for a slightly confused palate. 2013-03-20
Pours thick amber. Sour mash aroma with notes of apple. Well balanced sour and bitter up front that fades to pure lambic sour.

Appearance: orange, ~hazy, fluffy head. Aroma: lemon peel, biscuits. Only slightly sour. Slightly sweet. Light thin body, as brett tends to create. Just kind of flat all around. Theres nothing wrong with it, in the sense of off-flavors or large imbalances, just uninspiring. But it is refreshing, so I wouldnt refuse one if offered at a barbecue. Problem is, nobody will (price tag of around $6). If youre looking for a light summery beer, I would suggest the quintessential Saison Dupont.
Très juteux avec un brett timide et bien intégré. Des notes de conifères et de fleurs simposent de plus en plus, un surprenant mélange de la sauvagerie du brett dompter par la fougue des houblons.

Pours a hazy gold with a nice two finger head and little lace.  Smells mildly funky with a small bit of lemon zest.  Tastes pretty bland with a minor hint of funk and grain.  Moderately fizzy palate.  I think I will buy another because this cant be the same beer everyone else is drinking,

Nice golden color with a bubbly white head. Complex nose with lemon citrus, spice, and yeast. The taste front is yeast, lemon/orange citrus with a nice spice...nutmeg perhaps, finish is kind of like a bread flavor. Wonderful mouthfeel.

Pours a hazy bubbly orange with a decent amount of fizzy head. Nose is heavy yeast and then lemons and peaches. Starts with a hint of apples then finishes with the lemon tartness. Nice version of a sour ale.

bottle.  cloudy gold with large, lively, carbonation bubbles under a big, thick, fluffy, bleach white head.  dusty, brett aroma with hints of herbal hops.   highly carbonated palate with a clea, dry finish.  flavor has notes of bready malts with dusty brett, clean herbal/grassy hops, hints of butter and peaches.  i enjoyed this more than the regular devotion.

Bottle. Hazy golden pour with a lively white head. Aroma was lemon, peach and old books. Flavors were light fruit, some bready malt with a super dry finish. Very drinkable and refreshing. Plus carbonation, zingy mouthfeel.

375 ml bottle.  Aroma of barnyard funk, cobwebs, dust.  Mild dusty fruit.  Some peach, some pale malt.  Flavor is funky, dusty, bone dry.  Ghosts of fruit haunt its tendrils.  The pale malt is old, dusty, delicious.  This is incredible.  Nice slick mouthfeel, smooth finish.  This is fantastic.

Pours a murky orange with a big thick white head that lasts a while. Lacing is very nice. Aromas are spices, barnyard and a hint of alcohol. Bitterness is balance by some bready malts and lingering funk. I like Devotion and think the brett is a nice addition.

12.7oz bottle, 2013 Vintage.  Served at around 45F.

Pours hazy orange/gold with a huge rocky white head.  The head is impressive, slowly receding and leaving caves and crevices behind, leaving not clumps but freakin chunks of foam on the side of the glass.

Aroma is fruity and spicy.  Tart lemon, pineapple, tropical fruits, kiwi, sour green apple, yeast, touch of vinegar, hint of funk.  Brett is more in a fruity stage right now.  Very good strength.

Flavor is quite fruity, sour apple, lemon, tropical fruits, melon, kiwi, spicy, yeasty, some sweetness in the middle, tiny touch tart on the finish, mild alcohol.

Mouthfeel is medium bodied with sharp carbonation.

This is really good, the aroma in particular is delightful.  As far as how much it differs from their regular Devotion, I cant say, but stands up on its own as a great beer.  Gonna have to grab one more to throw in the cellar and let the Brett do its thing.

375 from greens. I was floored at the 5$ price tag so had to give it a whirl. Dark yellow color with big white head. Some banana and spice withe a touch of funkiness as you would expect from a Brett infused beer. Finish is a little spicey. Theres more here in this pleasant and complex drink. A definite value.

375ml bottle from bev4less. Pours a cloudy yellow-gold color with a big white head that has fair retention. The aroma is big with Belgian yeasts, hay, lemon, spices and brett. The taste was a bit sour with sour white grapes, Belgian yeasts, bitter lemon, hay, white pepper, and something a bit medicinal. The palate was light but effective with medium carbonation. Finished long and dry with a bit of lingering sourdough bread. Overall: Decent, but not very sour, and lots of large white floaties in this one.

Pours a cloudy golden orange-yellow with a bubbly white head.  Aroma is of citrus, wet hay,  baked bread, sour fruits, and some belgian yeast.  Taste is similar but has more funkyness, and includes some more earthiness.  Has a medium body with a slightly watery mouthfeel and a semi dry, funky, sour finish.  Overall, a tasty and interesting remake of devotion.
Bottle shared with the Utah crew. Huge thanks to Irish boy. Dusty, fruity, earthy, floral. Super tasty.

Bottle at a Lost Abbey dinner at Monks Cafe in Philly. Hazy yellow gold with a huge pillowy white head. Brett funk off the top. The underlying floral Saison is quite overtaken by the Brett but not in a bad way. Actually seems to heighten both the sweet and the bitter. Medium body. Grassy dry finish. Fantastic!
Cloudy yellow with lots of carbonation. Berry character and a sweet grainy malt. Sweet without too much tartness. Sweet finish with no aftertaste. Nice.

Great American Beer Festival, 2012. This was good.  It reminded of Orval, but not that good. Lots of yeast in the aroma, of a dry Belgian ale or even getting close to a dry saison. Some grain in the flavor. Very much a farmhouse character to this beer.
1pt 9.4oz bottle. Pours a gold color with slight head. Mild brett character show in aroma and flavor.light body with full mouthfeel. Pleasant.

2008 Vintage. 750ml, caged and corked bottle. Hazy golden color with an averaged sized off white head. Aromas of brett, yeast, musty, barnyard, manure, and earthy. Tastes of funk, bread, citrus, and a lighter fruitiness.

[2008] Hazy golden color with a medium sized, white head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of strong brett, vanilla, toffee, light spices, and some carboardy oxidation.  Taste of strong brett, some diapers, toasted malts, and more oxidation.

The beer pours unclear golden orange, quite nice, with a beautiful white creamy head. The aroma brings notes of soft sweet candy from the Brett, so lovely in the nose, with the wild yeast notes. The flavor brings the wild Brett yeast, which has not died at all after 4 years but is quite present. The body is quite full as well, juicy and nice with some citrus notes at the end.
Served in a Lost Abbey teku.  Smells quite fruity. Tropical notes and peach with backing earth. Dry and ever so slightly tart. Very nice; this has aged quite well.
Bottle thanks to IrishBoy! Pours a cloudy orange color with a large white head. A big nose of woody brett and hay. The flavor is lemons, very dry, Brett, fruity, white grapes. Good.

Bottle thanks to Irishboy 
Appearance: Hazy straw yellow with a small white head, light lacing 
Aroma: Tart fruit, brett and woody 
Taste: Tart, woody and oak 
Nice
Sugary, spicy flavor, with some subtle fruitiness (pear, maybe). Substantial Brett flavor. Moderate bitterness.

Shared by yourefragile. Thanks Michael.

The beer appears hazy and straw yellow with a thin white head that coats the glass in lacing. The aroma offers strong brettanomyces funk, malt. Smell and flavor dominated by brett. Very tasty. Light in body and easy drinking. A solid brew. I would definitely have this again.

750ml cork in cage bottle.  Straw colored, with a voluminous bubbly white froth that laces perfectly. Funky aroma with a bit of sour green apple, earth and stale bread. Tastes light and crisp with some subtle Brett character and biscuit notes. Strong carbonation, delicate body that finishes with a tiny bit of tartness. Highly drinkable and much more interesting than the standard version. Looking forward to trying this one after a few more months of aging.

Sample at GABF 10/13/2012, thanks to Bluemeow76 for assistance with note-taking. The beer is a clear golden color with a medium foamy white head and small patches of lace. Aroma of funky fruit, spice and yeast. Medium body with a moderately sour Brett character and notes of citrus, yeast and some earthy malt. The finish is tart and fruity. Good all around.

Shared at a Lost Abbey sour tasting. Poured a orange-yellow color with a white head. Aroma was a yeast character, with plenty of farmhouse notes. Interesting brew. Sweet malt notes - funk character is interesting. Enjoyable.
hazy gold, thin white head with heavy lacing. Heavy cedar nose, light milk and grains. Heavy cedar and pineapple, toast, light milk, very pleasant. High carbonation, but offsetting but nice overall.

Bottle shared by BigGirlPanties.  Pours clear gold with a medium, frothy white head, medium retention with good lacing.  Aroma is heavy phenols, light spicy hops and fruits, straw and meal malt.  Flavor is phenols, earthy and barnyard, light hops and bitterness, and very dry finish.  Medium body, warmth, and carbonation.

Bottle shared by biggirlpanties: pours a clear deep golden with a spotty-lacing white head. Has a mostly dry earthy nose with some grassy hay and funk notes.  Starts with some mild sweetness and mild lemongrass tartness with dry earthy funk and horseblanket notes before a drier earthy bitter finish.

Bottle. Pours hazy gold with average, fizzy white head; short retention and minimal lacing. Aroma is oranges, biscuit and straw malt, yeast, floral hops, and some plastic bandage. Flavor is balanced malt and fruit esters with faint plastic undertones; dry, lightly bitter finish. Light/medium body,medium carbonation, and low warmth.
UPDATED: FEB 4, 2013 Poured at Lost Abbey dinner a couple years ago. Light carbonation, minimal hops. Flavor and body were weak as well. Brett was barely detectable. Alright, original is much better.

750 mL bottle, corked & caged, from the 2010 saints membership, sampled Sept 2011:  slitly hazed, orange gold...with a perfectly persistent ivory cream that leaves a thick lace.  Strawberry, sweet butterscotch and honey blossom aroma that has slightly funky undertones with freshly cut hay and touches of horse blanket.  Perfectly carbonated, tingling the lips and lively through to the back of my mouth...the Brett begins to come out in the flavor very quickly, lighty acidic and sour...just short of making your lips pucker.  Truly a world class effort, thank you!  I could drink one of these every day!

On tap for a Port/Lost Abbey night at Brouwers. Golden apricot color - opaque, with a tiny head. Nice aroma - honey wheat, and sweet citrus - but the flavor brings it off. *Super* dry - the brett seems to have dried it to the bone -- some unbaked (yeasty) rosemary bread and dusty orange, but lacking in complexity and far too dry.

Thanks to theEpeest. Pours hazy golden with wispy white head. Nice citrus orange peel, light spice, brett funk cuts beligan spice thing that regular devotion has going on. Not very sour, which is nice, with grain and spice action in taste. Glad i got to try.

26th May 2009Cloudy orange beer. Just a very thin white head. Soft palate tending to slightly dry. Comes over as a Saison, aromatic and fruity but also quite funky. Sourish and almost creamy finish and quite a bitter aftertaste. A bit different!

750 ml poured by drewbeerme or pantanap. Thanks! Pours a rich golden hazy hue, bright white frothy head laces well, stays as a thicker ring, with some good haze. Aromas are rich deep brett moving into fruity esters, some lemon and apple, with dry horseblanket, hay, and dust. Fruity. Initial is lighter bodied with a huge brett influence, dry dusty, hay, and horseblanket, dry funky brett hits some cheesiness and moves into some bitterness its so intense. Middle moves into some bread, pale malts, back into fruit, really dry bretty finish. I was really a fan of this, the brett really works its way into the base Devotion, enveloping with great funk, fruity esters, dry, some wet old soft cheese. Quality, with a light spritzy body and fairly complex experience.

Thanks to Sean, 750ml bottle into my Rochefort. 

A dark honey gold with decent carbonation, light lacing...The aroma is musky grass, light grapefruit, very similar to the sauvingon blanc..Taste is lightly sweet, more grass with brett not super sour just a tad, then a light chalk finish which is a little offputting.

A light grassy brett beer, pretty refreshing, but a little light and tough.

UPDATED: JUN 25, 2011 Bottle. Really fantastic flavors and textures to this beer. Farmhouse, earthy and citrus zest. The texture is a light to medium bodied with with a dry finish that has excellent lively carbonation too .

Wow, this beer is awesome.   Really, really awesome.  Funky farmhouse aromas all up on this one, but also a great herbal/floral/earthy hoppy component that just does wonderfully with the funk.  And theres a ton of pie crust/cookie/biscuit/cake god damn this beer is awesome.

bottle shared with MrBunn, picked up from my 1 year as a Saint. Pours a hazy golden hue with some white foam that diminishes and lasts.  Somewhat musty aroma, with elements of hay and spice.  Happy beginning, spicy and light...  some sourness, but its mostly just light season type beer,  Good stuff.  Interested to see how the other bottle continues to age.
Shared with Mrbunn and Gorditoabd.  Smells nice.  Light golden color. Light and lightly sweet with a touch of must.

Bottle with love to gorditoabd for being a winner and a saint!  Pours a hazy light gold with a thin head and aromas of barn, lemon and pear.  Flavor is very light, with a light fruit sweetness, lemon zest and very light funk.  Very nice for a somewhat subdued beer.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text:
sampled 12/14/2008
Pours a slightly cloudy golden orange color with a massive bubbly head that sticks everywhere. Smells of spicy Belgian yeast a bit of funk, lots of fruit. Tastes of fruit, berries. Spicy and peppery. Smooth as hell with a sour twang. The brett sourness is there, but not dominant. Nice in its subtlety. Mouth is smooth creamy body is medium to thin. Carbonation is medium. Very interesting brew, I enjoyed this bottle and look forward to the others after a little time in the cellar.

UPDATED: AUG 15, 2014 Bottle. 25.4 oz. Lost Abbey Dinner 2011. Pours a transparent cider golden with a thin, sudsy, tightly-bubbled off-white head, No lacing. Aroma of Belgian candieed  sugars, lemon zeat, farmhoue funk, and banana, green apple, and bitter hop. Thin, nearly effervescent body with a dry, slightly tart mouthfeel. Brett and hay flavors overwhelm the tongue for a s super dry, classy finish. Very good, but I like the standard bettter.

Re-rate:
Bottle. Pours raw honey with a fuzzy off-white head. Aroma is peach, fresh tart strawberry, Granny Smith apple skins, green grapes, and some beautiful, earthy Brett. Flavor is dry stone fruit, salinity, and mellow bitter hop in the finish. Balanced, elegant and restrained. A wonderful beer, especially on a nice summer night alongside a pretty woman.

UPDATED: OCT 27, 2016 Bottle split with Linh at lost abbey. Pours a bright orange body with small white lacing. Aroma is delicious yeast, wheat, and Brett. Mouthfeel is nicely carbonated with Belgian spices, clove, yeast - the Brett effect is great. RESAMPLED: Bottle poured at GABF 2016 with Paul and Larry. Honestly may have been one of the worst beers of the entire weekend. Its been years since Ive had most Lost Abbey offerings, but this really caught me by surprise; tons of burnt plastic and rubber tire rendered this essentially undrinkable. 2.4/5.0 Though, going to keep my original rating and give Tomme the benefit of the doubt.

Golden pour with a vibrant white froth. Tons of brett in the aroma- juicy nectar and citrus give way to some nice spicy and doughy notes. Puckering brett dryness and excellently powerful flavors. Better than the original.

750 ml bottle shared by beastiefan2k. Pour is a hazed cloudy orange, with more or less no head. Aroma is mild floral and grain, Brett creeps up in the back. Taste is dry, flinty with Brett onion skin, some vegetal notes. Palate is medium bodied, coats the mouth a bit, lowish carbonation.  Thanks Eugene.

750ml bottle generously shared thanks to Bardwashrind on BA, a very generous guy.  Pours slightly hazy golden-copper in color with a lasting white head and good lacing.  Big bretty funk on the aroma, with notes of barnyard, hay, and sheeps wool (my favorite).  Some slight fruit and hop notes as well.  The flavor is bretty and slightly tart but not at all sour.  Well more funky than tart Id say.  Theres a great tropical fruit/pineapple note, citrus peel, and earth.  Medium-bodied with a nice lively carbonation to it and a crisp mouthfeel.  Excellent beer over all from The (in this case not so) Flat Abbey.

Very appealing aroma of brett, yeast, hops, citrus and hay. Pours a hazy yellow color with a thin white head. Excellent flavor of brett, hay, yeast, citrus and hops with some bitterness in the end. The body is light to medium with a creamy texture and medium to lively carbonation. Amazing.

750ml bottle pours a hazy, orange, yellow with a creamy white head.  Aroma is a little like a country fair, cotton candy, horses, grassy, hay.  Flavor is very tart, musty, dirt, grass.  More funk in the nose than the flavor.  Finish is dry.

hazy orange with a nice size white head.  Aroma is yeasty dough,  barnyard,  and leather.  Flavor has a nice peppery bite to it.  Plenty of brett showing through along with some hop grassiness and fruity yeast.  Finishes dry,  nice carbonation.  Very good.
Big bretty nose, lots of horseblanket, light lemon, hay and cotton candy. Taste is cotton candy, bretty funk, light honey, lemon and lots of hay. Soft and smooth. Very nice.

750mL courtesy of pittsburghkid. Pours a hazy orange with a decent white head that leaves very sheety/excellent lace. Aroma is full of Brett, florals, resiny wood, cedar closet, bright fruits, fresh white peppercorn, some horsey notes. Whoa. Taste is spicy, Bretty, white grape skins, some soapy hops. Very saison-like.
Slightly hazy bright yellow, fizzy carbonation, edge head.  Aroma of slightly sour apricot, vanilla, barnyard.  Good balance, good character.

Bottle that Garrett got for me a while back.   Pours out a copper color without much of a head.  Head goes away quick, leaving nothing really.  Smell is basically the same as devotion with a little bit of sour funk, but not much.  Taste is almost identical to devotion.  There is a little funk, but I am not sure its even good funk.   Kinda not the best thing I have had from LA.  At least it was carbonated.

Bottle from LA tasting room.  Pours a hazy golden hay color with white head.  Light fruit, grass, bready malt, light funk, and a touch of tartness.  Balanced, light, and easy drinking.  I much prefer the Saints Red Barn, the brett in this beer is only slightly noticable.

Blind tasting at PapsøsCloudy deep blond and orange color; medium creamy head. Sourish aroma, some Bretts, light harsh fruitness, citrus fruit peel. Medium mouthfeel, fairly smooth malt, light fruits, with a quite aggressive bitterness, Brett-type, light astringency too as expected. Good bitterness level. Quite good, well brewed, balanced; interesting.
Bottle from the giving tree. Orange with a fluffy white head. Lemon zest and yeast aroma. Crisp and refreshing citrus taste with a nice balance between the hops bitterness and the Brett sourness.

Bottle.  Poured goldish orange, clear with a little haze to it.  Big white head and some lace.  Aroma of wheat, spice, fruit/citrus, yeast, brett.  Taste is really nice, with lots of yeast, fruit, some brett, spice, light funk.  Finish is light hop bitter.  Mouth is really light and carbonated.  Very nice brew.

Bottle 75cl. @ Papsoes blindtasting. [ Bottle #9. ]Unclear medium orange color with a average, creamy to frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white to white head. Aroma is moderate malty, brett, spices, light to moderate hoppy, fruity, moderate yeasty, barnyard. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and moderate bitter with a average to long duration, and a dry finish. Body is medium, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft. [20090612]
This beer I liked, pour was a cloudy golden color.  Aroma of yeast, wheat, lesser notes of brett.  Flavor is top notch, quite tasty and very drinkable.  Refreshing as heck.

Cloudy golden colro with a small head fades fast. Aroma is brett, sourness and some citrus. Flavor is faint brett, some funk, some mellow sourness. Just a bit light overall. A nice drinkable bretty belgian but nothing spectacular.

Bottled. An unclear golden beer with a lazing off-white head. The aroma has notes of brettanomyces, lacto, malt, and citrus. The flavor is rather sweet with notes of wood, brettanomyces, wheat, and fruit, leading to a dry wheaty and slightly tart finish. Thanks Papsoe for sharing.
#09 - Amerikaner Blind-Smagning 12-Jun-2009 hos Papsoe. Bottle. Clear golden - white head. Pie, horsey, fruity, brett, crispy, dryness, milkey, wheaty, light yeasty, licorice yeasty. Nice.

From bottle, blind #9. Pours cloudy to hazy yellow with a small white head. Dry brettish and wheaty aroma. Dry brett and caramel malt flavoured, subdued sweetness. Light spice and hoppy note to this. Light bitter acidity slowly coming through into the finish. Lasting brett finish.

Bottle 75 cl. Courtesy of bu11zeye. Hazy and opaque orangey golden with an off-white head. Aroma of yeast and Brett. Light body, dry fruit and yeast with dry and slightly astringent Brett accents. A little yeast and dry, astringent phenols in the finish. But quite refreshing really. 120609

Bottle #9 at Papsøs blindtasting. 
Hazy golden coloured with a medium sized white head.
Fruity aroma of spices and brett.
Fruity flavour of spices, hops and brett.
Bretty and spicy finish.

In short: A very very wild and well hopped brew.  Kick-ass.
How: Bottle 750ml.  Tasting session with Montreal crew.  Mega-thanks to beerbuzzmontreal for this gem.
The look: Cloudy orange-yellow body topped by a very small white head
In long: Superb nose of barnyard.  In mouth the beer feels very wild and very alive.  Somehow not so bretty but definitely very wild, like a very wild barnyard Saison.  Flavours of cookies, fruits (but not specific fruits), a bit juicy, sweetness reminiscent of a freshly baked pie crust.  Rather hoppy with plenty of floral hops.  Light juicy bitterness.  Wonderful beer.  The only way Ill ever find a better Devotion is to go out with a very very ugly girl who knows Im her last hope.

My Bottom Line:
Bountiful floral hops expand atop biscuity cereals and coniferous brettanomyces impressions before earthy hops establish courteous bitterness and dryness compels one to get another big gulp of this very handsome Wild Ale.

Further Personal Perceptions:
-A veil of foam covers the cloudy beige-orange.
-Carbonation is frothy but soft, and the mouthfeel is healthily authentic.
-This might have a stronger finish than the regular Devotion?
-The earthy hoppiness and the brett work amazingly well together.

Bottle.

Bottle at RnH Drink for Charity.  Thanks to everyone who brought great beer to this.  Golden orange with head and lace.  Funky spicy orange aroma.  Brett spicy pineapple with heavy spicy finish.  Nice texture.  Very tasty.

Bottle at the Drink for Charity event at Rattle & Hum. Pours a hazy yellow with a thin white head.  Light funk, wood, and cork aromas.  Medium bodied.  Little bit funky, sweet and fruity.  Finishes with a light bitterness.
Bottle shared by JoeMcPhee.  Pours a hazy golden body with a white head.  Dry spicy tangy citrus brett and wild floral aroma with a leather mouth feel and a moderately sharp carbonation.

[Bottle] shared by STLWill. Pours a little bit hazier than the regular version, smells very spicy, which comes of as a hoppiness not unlike saaz. More herbal and more earthy than the regular version. Flavor matches the aroma to a T.

Sampled from 750 bottle and shared by STLWill. Pours a semi-hazy orange amber colored brew with a decent off-white head that slowly dissipates to a thin white ring with some spotty lacing. Aroma of fruity apple/pear, some golden grain malt with wheat, some Belgian yeast, banana and funky Brett. Taste is slightly tart, some carbonation with flavors of caramel, horse blanket, some Brett funk, orange zest and a touch of Christmas potpourri. Finish is slightly tart with some lemon zest and tart fruit fruit aftertaste.

Courtesy Beerlando.  Slightly cloudy orange color with an even thin white head.  Excellent floral aroma, slight sweet grains, bready funk, complex.  Dry taste to start, nice Brett component, Belgian yeast, flowers.  Excellent.

UPDATED: JUN 21, 2009 CPLYFO 09.  Pours a blond slight hazy with a nice white head- fluffy and sticky good lace.  Aroma is big toasty and bready pils malts, yeasty, phenolic, hints of citrus and grapefruit with a fruit estery profile- strange phenolics with a horse blankety and tropical fruit brett character.  Bretty with fresh dough but also some dirty horse, funk, and weird acetates- acids, esters, and a green hop presence.  Finish is funky and smooth with a great dry aftertaste.  This was really nice, but not phenomenal.  I liked it better than regular Devotion so thats good.

25.4 oz bottle.  Clear orange with a sudsy white head.  Nose is apple, light lemon, peach, apricot and a touch of barnyard.  Medium body with buzzy carb; a touch oily.  Taste is lemon marmalade, sharp green grass and honey.  Dry peppery finish.  The brett is only mildly apparent.

UPDATED: MAY 14, 2011 750 ml bottle, Thanks pantanap for sharing this brew!  Pours a hazed orange with a white creamy head.  Fresh green hoppy, spicy, and slightly funky aroma.  Tart orange caramel malt flavors with an enjoyable hop bitterness and brett funkiness.  The brett is pretty slight and Id like to see more of it, but its still enjoyable at this stage.  Funky, hoppy, tasty, and drinkable beer.  Thanks Kan!

DLD11.  Thanks to andrew for this pour.
Malts and citrus aromas. Sole sweet dough and distinctive Brett. Similar flavors with a good amount of Brett. Earthy light bitter flavors.  Deco.  I like the original better.  7/3/8/3/15

Side by Side with Devotion thanks to Beerlando. Orangish color, slightly cloudy. White foamy head. Citrusy spicy nose with some light horseblanket. Flavor is pretty similar to the devotion. Lots of spicy yeast, orange peel and citrus. A slight hint of tartness but its very faint. Could use more brett. Solid saison like belgian though.
Bottle.  Orangish/gold color with a white head.  Aroma is full of citrus, funk and malty.  Flavor is funky, tart, some fruitiness and a tad of yeast.  Just ok.

Pours hazy gold to orange with a moderate creamy white head.  Carbonated, woohoo!  Um, aroma is really nice with some pine, mustard, toast, oak, vague hints of vinegar; good brett presence.  Tastes more rounded toast, oak, citrus rind, pine mustard and less vinegar notes, but theyre around.  Finishes bitter, woody and with a bit rotten fruit.  Medium bodied, creamy, still light enough to be easy drinking.  Its Devotion with a well behaved Brett presence, and its easy to imagine how it would taste.  Still, its good.
Pours bright golden with a thin white head. The nose is citrus and brett, ads is the flavor. Lively mouthfeel and tart finish.

Sampled on 2/21/2009. This Belgian Ale pours a medium orange gold color from a 750ml-corked bottle. Medium sized white foamy head, with nice retention. The aroma is fruity and sweet with a touch of must and funk. A medium bodied Belgian Ale. The malts are fruity and sweet, with some orange peel. There is a touch of funk, must and leather. The hops are floral and earthy. A fairly big hop bite, especially for a Belgian Ale. . Nice balance. Good carbonation. It probably could use some more bottle aging, its just now starting to dry out. Nice crisp dry finish with a soft delicate palate. The mouthfeel is full and round. The finish is crisp and nicely dry. The aftertaste is slightly sweet with some dryness.

Special thanks to Beerlando for providing this side by side with Devotion.  The differences arent much more than the brett.  The bitterness in the regular Devotion is still there, now with a great kick from the brett.  Nice and funky, with grass and dust.  Very good.

750ml bottle. thanks to Pantanap for sharing! pours hazy bright gold with foamy white head. nose is floral, bretty barnyard notes. the flavor is grassy, dry, herbal, touch of brett funk to it, pale malt finish. med body, could use a little more time to let the funk out. but this is still a wonderful drink.

UPDATED: FEB 23, 2009 750ml bottle thanks to bleeng...pours a semi-trans orange brown with a soapy white head...def more of a tropical fruit sensation with pineapple accents than regular devotion.  brett makes a considerable difference in this one....flavors were semi sweet with subdued hops but a much added improvement was the brettiness that gave it a slight funk that meshed well with the pear accents.

Bottle. Light amber beer with a whitish head. Bretty aroma with light lemon. Tart flavor with plenty of brett and a bit of barnyard. Medium bodied. Breadiness lingers with the brett - tart and barnyard.

Bottle shared by Beerlando. Pours cloudy gold/orange color with off white head. Big brett aroma is the first to hit the nose with a light fruity aroma and some grassy hops. Flavor is lots of brett funkiness, sweet fruity flavor, light grassy hops, pepper and a drier finish than the plain version. Light to medium body with lively carbonation.

Bottle via Bu11zeye, thanks ! Clear dark golden color with a white head. Nice earthy brett aromas of barnyard piss and dry hay. Medium body with a frothy mouthfeel. Nice yeasty, earthy, spicy flavors on a dusty pale malt base brew. Very good.

text: Courtesy Beerlando. Pours a hazy golden orange color with a foamy, white head that settles quickly. The aroma shows notes of citrus, grassy hops, grains, and dry, barnyard funk from the brett. The flavor follows with the funky brett yeast and tart citrus along with the grassy hop bitterness. The brett really comes through in the flavor. Medium bodied, dry and peppery. Ample carbonation lends perfectly with the bretty yeast. I really like how the brett added another dimension to the regular devotion. Good stuff.

Pours a pale yellow hue, small white head dissipates, hazy clarity. Nose of spicey phenols, light fruits, grassy hops, and farmhouse funk. Flavor is light bret funk and grassy hops mostly, grainy malts, spices, light fruits (PEARS) round out the profile, finishes dry. Medium-bodied, smooth texture, high carbonation. A nice variation on the regular, hops and bret provide a nice punch here.

Tasted back to back with the regular, non-brett Devotion.  Pours a lightly hazy orange-amber color with a foamy, off white head.  Scant flares and spots of lacing mark the glass.  The aroma shows a big brett presence, very reminiscent of a Jolly Pumpkin brew.  Dry, dusty, funky brett changes the whole profile of the underlying grainy sweetness and sharp, grassy hops.  Flavors follow suit, funky brett yeast and hints of tartness enhancing the honey glazed grains and zesty citrus and grass bitterness.  Medium bodied and even more dry and peppery than the regular version, the lively carbonation works better in a bretty beer in my opinion.  Basically, this brew smells, tastes, and feels like a cross between the regular Devotion and Bam Biere.  Great stuff.

Bottle... GSRARO Throwdown... Murky pear-colored ale with a small, creamy, white head. Good retention. Herbal, yeasty, lightly acidic, mildly spicy nose. Medium-bodied with lively carbonation. Well-balanced, dry flavor of  pale malts and warm bread. No funkiness, no tartness - just a crisp, bone-dry finish provided by the Brett.  Thanks to Beerlando for sharing this bottle of beer with everyone!
Hazy yellow. Peppery and bretty with a touch of grapeskin tannin, neat. Moderate fruity funk. Dry finish and slightly tannic.

Huge sample from $12 750mL bottle at OBriens generously bought and poured by WeeHeavySD.  I really like this beer.  I apparently got the dregs, because my glass was cloudy light yellow, vs other glasses that were clear light yellow.  In general I much prefer cloudy beers.  My nose is working hard to smell the Brett with lots of difficulty, nevertheless it smells wonderful.  Maybe the smallest amount of acidity, but certainly not sour.  Insanely easy to drink.  I love Devotion, so it makes sense I would like Saints Devotion.  Really great beer.

750 from the Patron Saints Club - thanks, Tomme! Lustrous pale orange pour with a fairly lively head and some sticky retention. The nose is far more earthy than I recall, with yeast, grass, and some mild spice from regular Devotion blending nicely with brett. Yup, its there even after a few months. The base beer has always been very dry and funky, and even at this age the wild stuff is getting it on with the more prim and proper beer at bottom. Slightly fruity, tangy hops, playful mouthfeel that brings the flavors to the fore. Lovely.

Bottle thanks to a trade with Hank1980. Shared with Tyler and the folks at the Bruery. Pours a hazy golden color with a small, off-white head, good lacing and decent retention. Aroma is similar to Devotion, with dryness and a bit of fruit and a touch of brett earthiness. Taste is very different from the regular Devotion, quite phenolic. Tons of strong brett-iness that is very earthy and only slightly tart. Dry mouthfeel with light carbonation.

750ml at Obriens.  Shared with AlohaC, wetherel, and some other people.  After trading for this beer with ratman, and bonused by Hannont I get this at Obriens for $12.  12 bucks, damn, I couldnt pass this up.  Pours yellow orange with a bright white head with a ton of lacing.  Nose is sweet light and somewhat tart.  There is some tobacco in the air that muffled the nose.  Taste is tart funky and light with some barnyard which is nice.  Bret is there and this will certainly get better with time.  Nice.

Bottle.  Pours a hazy pale orange color with a nice white head that settles into a thin lacy one.  Smells of herbs/spices with a slight tangyness to it.  Tastes similar with the tangy funkiness coming out more.  Really a steller beer.

UPDATED: FEB 17, 2011 2008 release; sampled January 2009; Served at ~58°F / 14.4°C into my large Tripel Karmeliet tulip. 
The beer starts out with a four-finger thick, dense, tan-tinged, off-white colored head.  The head leaves lots of lacing sticking to the sides of my glass and it also forms some rocky & mesa like structures as it slowly recedes.  The beer is a pale-red tinged, honey color that shows a brilliantly clear orange-gold color when held up to the light.  The aroma is nice and hoppy with notes of hay, lemon grass, a touch of pine needles and a nice herbal note.  Underneath this the Brettanomyces is noticeable; it is still pretty subtle, but contributes aromas of rubber, a touch of muskiness, and a soft barnyard note.  There is also some sweet, grassy grain character and some cracker like malt that I noticed as I was trying to figure out the Brett aromatics.

The beer has a dry, grassy and herbal character to it up front.  The middles sees a peppery carbonation and the Brettanomyces kicks in with some tongue coating phenolics that remind me of rubber and musk.  A light malt sweetness in the finish helps accentuate (or maybe it is the other way around) some fruit notes reminiscent of pear and apple.  This beer is quite light bodied, which is very nice, though there is a certain palate fullness to this beer that seems to be wrapped up somehow in the Brett phenolics.  This has an almost velvety texture to it that is quite nice in a beer that is this dry, light and effervescent as this is.  The hop character provides a nice bitter hop bite as well as a touch of lemon zest citrus character that morphs into a Meyer lemon note and then even tart orange (this moves more towards orange as the beer warms, though it never loses the lemon zest entirely); there is also a nice herbal component that mixes with the Brettanomyces phenolics.  There is a hint of cracker like malt flavor to the finish as well as a grassy grain note that gets wrapped up in the hop character.

I definitely like this a bit more than the standard Devotion, the Brett adds that little something extra to this nicely hoppy Belgianesque ale.  The sharp Brett notes actually compliment the hop character.  I really wished I hadnt missed out on picking up a couple extras of this beer, one is simply not enough.
Very funky. The brett changes this beer dramatically from a nice ale to a funk bomb. Almost like an old school farmhouse style with some hint at the Devotion we knew before.

Appearance: Pours a hazy, pale yellow body with a frothy, delicate, snow white head.

Smell: Lets see what we have here. Lightly malty, pleasantly floral aroma with fruity notes of pear juice and melon and encapsulated by a restrained, funky Brett component.

Taste: Slight pale malts and a meager sweetness. Floral, fruity aspects with a distant hint of spiced sourdough. Sip of still mineral water. All the while, lightly funky Brett tastes weave in and out of the flavor, imparting cotton, dust-covered cobwebs, and old leather bound books. Belated pithy, herbal hops and bitterness. Finishes bone dry and rather crisp.

Mouthfeel: Medium-thin body. Moderate carbonation.

Drinkability: A tasty upgrade to the standard Devotion. The somewhat more subtle Brett addition allows for some fine penetrating complexities without losing sight of the original beer or suffering from lack of drinkability.
Bottle. Aroma and flavor dominated by brett. Flavor of citrus, bread, hay, and brett. If you are a fan of regular Devotion and the flavor brett adds you will love this.

Shared by JoeMcPhee.  This may be the best LA beer that is brett-centric. It  pours a thick golden color that one cannot see through.  The aroma is floral and dry brettiness.  The taste is lightly sweet tropical fruits.  Its an extremely nice balance of brett and Devotion.  I like the regular Devotion, so I already liked part of the beer.  The brett is also coming through very nicely, which again is not often a given with LA brews.  And it all works well together.  For me this is much better than the Brouwers Saison and the old Synergy, which are supposed to be very similar brews. And the brett is definitely much better than in GOTM or 10 Commandments. Thanks again Joe.  Its like every time I get decide I hate LA then I have something actually good.

text: Pale amber beer with a thin white head.  Aroma is lovely.  Soft and lightly citrusy.  Lemon and a light soft fruity backnote.  Earthy and soft with a nice flinty character.  The cologney brett character is really coming out... crisp minerally maltiness and a light herbal hoppiness that work really well with one another.  This is a vast improvement on the original version.  Lovely.

750 ml bottle from Saints membership. Nose of caramel, vanilla, light piney hops, light spiciness, and yeast. Lightly hazy gold with a medium, glass lacing offwhite head. Flavor has light hop bitterness, peppery spiciness, and caramel. No real sourness, where is the brett? Tastes like the regular Devotion.

750ml bottle. Tart brett, grassy yeast and earthy hop aroma. A hint of earthy, dirty funkiness. Bread crust and hay bale. A touch of dried fruit skin. Pours a thick, hazed, dark orange with a creamy white head. Flavor is mostly dry and grassy. The tart, pineapple brett comes through on the finish. Very dry and crisp. Quite earthy. Leaf pile, aged hops, cut grass. Insanely drinkable. Tart and dry yeast and the brett meld together quite well. Creamy texture. Spritzy carbonation. Dry, earthy and slightly tart finish. Thanks Andy... a truly outstanding trader.
Shared by IrishBoy.  Gold amber with a thin white head.  Aroma is hoppy, piney, yeast.  Taste is a nice hoppiness, yeast and a subtle sweetness.
(sample from irishboy)cloudy yellow with a nice white head.aroma is mostly hops and yeast.flavor is yeast,wheat,hay,and hops.

750 ml corked and caged bottle poured a clear tarnished gold with a lasting creamy eggshell head. Aromas ofpear, citrus, barnyard, leather and straw. Palate was light to medium bodied and smooth with dry lightly tart finish. Flavors of straw, barnyard, light fruittinerss and hints of leather and spice with a smooth dry lightly tart lingering bitter finish.

750ml bottle from the brewery.  Pours a lightly hazed medium golden color with a light orange tint.  Also held a big fluffy off white head with great lacing.  Nose was very "bretty" with some clove, banana and citrus mixed in.  The Brett was very apparent in this brew, another great one from Tomme and his crew.

750 bottle. Bright, hazy gold color with a huge white fluffy head. No hiding the brett in the nose, along with a tanginess and spices. Taste is tart and spicy with a very light body. The flavors fall off on the end however. The brett is evident but does not overwhelm the drinkability of this beer. Very young , effervescent and eminently drinkable.

text: This poured a hazy golden orange in color with a thick head of medium-sized white bubbles that faded away.  The nose was very Belgian with scents of yeast, candi sugar, citrus and spice.  In the mouth it was medium-bodied with nice midpalate concentration that is balanced by a zippy tartness running through.  This was a real enjoyment due to the balance and wealth of flavor.

Bottle from a trade from a BA member.  Poured a hazy deep golden color, earthy and grassy aromas with an underlying bretty aroma.  Flavor is similar, very dry in the finish.  A very nice take on the original Devotion, not sure which one I like better, but this is quite good.

text:
UPDATED: DEC 13, 2008 Bottle shared by RustyDiamond poured into a goblet.

Pours a hazy golden yellow with a big soapy white head that lingers for a while and leaves great lacing.

The aroma was sweet with light fruits, apples and pears, and some grains. The brett is really subtle and the Belgian yeast is just as prominent with a spiciness that tingles the nose. The hops were present but not dominant.

The taste was slightly more funky, especially as it warmed, but the underlying Belgian characteristics were the most dominant - Belgian yeast, spiciness with some light fruits. The hops hit the tongue right up front but fade a bit as the brett presence grows.

This mouthfeel is very light and crisp with the hops and brett playing together on the palate. The carbonation accentuates the light mouthfeel.

Not the best Ive had from Lost Abbey but a very, very drinkable beer that uses brett as a subtle, not overpowering element.
A lightly hazy yellow with massive white head. A dry aroma with hops, yeast and brett funk. Fantastic funky body thats crisp dry and refreshing.
Pours an opaque golden with small white head. When I opened the bottle, there was hardly anything to be heard. The flavor has a nice balance of funk, citrus and sweetness. Pretty tasty.

Tasted courtesy of Obriens rare bottle tasting night. Light golden color with whitish head. Light citrus aromas with some yeasty undertones. Good funky brett flavor along with the typical light Devotion taste. Light mouthfeel. Nice added touch.

Pours hazy gold with a small white head and good lacing.  Wheaty, bretty funk in the nose.  Taste was dry; sourdough dough with a rye-ish bread crust.  Melons and wheat with light citrus.  Very bretty.
(Draught)  Pours a hazy golden body with a small off-white head.  Aroma of grass, floral, honeydew, and oak.  Flavor of florals, citrus, light brett, and some herbs with a oak finish.

Tap at Night of the Funk. Piny nose, very thin, vegetal, pale, dull. Flavor is alright. Yeasty, a touch of oak, a hint of sour. Not much in the way of barnyard characteristics. I think this needs to see some aging for the brett to show a presence, though I don’t think it’s the kind of beer that would do well with any horsiness.
Bottle from 08 Night of the Funk. Straight up a bretted up Devotion, and tasty.

Bottle sampled on 09/26/08 at Night of the Funk.  Pours a cloudy yellow with a thick white head.  Aroma of melon, citrus, Belgian yeast, and wheat.  Flavor of Belgian yeast with a slight tinge of citrusy hops.  Slight tartness.  Pretty much exactly as advertised: a bretted up version of Devotion.  In my opinion, its an improvement!  Quite tasty and delicious.
